analysis.title: This Wedding Is Fucked
analysis.author: Erica Bardin & Susan Graham
analysis.logline: When recently broken-up exes are forced to be maid of honor and best man at a destination wedding, their escalating revenge war destroys the entire resort.

act_architecture.note: Clear three-act structure with well-defined turning points

scene_necessity.note: Most scenes earn their place, some feel indulgent

momentum.note: Good escalation through revenge pranks to climactic destruction

payoff_delivery.note: Excellent payoffs for setup elements like the ring, photos, and relationship dynamics

structure.justification: Solid structural foundation with clear act breaks and escalating conflict
page_citations: Page 11: Inciting incident - couple breaks up on Jonathan's big night
Page 41: Midpoint - shark attack/ring loss escalates stakes
Page 89: Climax - hotel destruction forces resolution
structure.weakness_identified: Second act occasionally meanders with some scenes feeling more episodic than essential

scene_construction.note: Generally solid scene construction with clear objectives

visual_storytelling.note: Good visual comedy and physical gags throughout

economy.note: Some scenes run long, action blocks occasionally verbose

scene_writing.justification: Competent scene craft with strong visual comedy elements
page_citations: Page 39-41: Shark attack sequence - excellent visual comedy escalation
scene_writing.weakness_identified: Tendency toward overwriting in action blocks and some scenes that don't advance story efficiently

voice_distinction.note: Characters have distinct voices, especially Nicole's Type-A lawyer speak

subtext_quality.note: Some good subtext but often characters say exactly what they mean

functionality.note: Dialogue serves plot and character adequately

speakability.note: Generally speakable but some lines feel written rather than spoken

dialogue.justification: Solid character voices with good comic timing
page_citations: Page 14: Nicole's legal pep talk - 'I don't like grey areas' - perfectly captures her character
dialogue.weakness_identified: Could use more subtext and natural speech patterns in emotional moments

goal_clarity.note: Clear goal to 'win' against Jonathan at the wedding

active_agency.note: Drives many plot points but sometimes reactive

arc_credibility.note: Growth from selfish to selfless feels somewhat rushed

investment.note: Likable but her actions make her hard to root for at times

protagonist.justification: Melissa is a flawed but relatable protagonist whose revenge quest provides clear motivation
page_citations: Page 6: Goal established through wanting to focus on photography career vs. Jonathan's suburban dreams
protagonist.weakness_identified: Her more extreme actions (kidnapping plot) push audience sympathy too far

character_distinction.note: Each character has a unique voice and personality

functional_purpose.note: Characters serve story while maintaining individual identity

ensemble_balance.note: Good ensemble work though some characters underused

supporting_cast.justification: Strong supporting characters with distinct personalities
page_citations: Page 22-26: Bradford's introduction - perfectly establishes his character through action and dialogue
supporting_cast.weakness_identified: Some characters like Edward feel more like comic relief than fully realized people

relationship_dynamics.note: Complex, evolving relationships especially between sisters

emotional_stakes.note: We care about some relationships more than others

relationships.justification: The central relationships drive the story effectively with real emotional weight

freshness.note: Fresh take on wedding comedy and revenge plots

execution_independence.note: Strong concept that would work with average execution

premise.justification: Compelling premise that immediately suggests conflict and comedy
page_citations: Title card structure effectively sets up the escalating timeline

thematic_clarity.note: Clear themes about love, compromise, and personal growth

organic_integration.note: Themes emerge naturally from character conflicts

complexity.note: Nuanced view of relationships and personal ambition

resonance.note: Universal themes about balancing love and personal dreams

theme.justification: Strong thematic content that gives depth to the comedy

authorial_voice.note: Distinctive comedic voice with good character work

tonal_consistency.note: Maintains raunchy comedy tone throughout with heart

genre_awareness.note: Good understanding of romantic comedy conventions

confidence.note: Confident execution of comedic set pieces

voice_and_tone.justification: Solid comedic voice that knows its genre well

traps_evaluated.name: premise_execution_gap
traps_evaluated.assessment: Minimal gap between premise strength and execution quality

traps_evaluated.name: first_act_illusion
traps_evaluated.first_act_quality: Strong setup with good character establishment

traps_evaluated.name: character_vacuum
traps_evaluated.assessment: We care about the characters, especially the sisters' relationship

traps_evaluated.name: dialogue_disguise
traps_evaluated.assessment: Scenes work visually independent of dialogue

traps_evaluated.name: complexity_theater
traps_evaluated.assessment: Themes are clear: balancing personal dreams with love and commitment

traps_evaluated.name: originality_inflation
traps_evaluated.assessment: Underlying story is compelling even without stylish execution

major_weaknesses: Protagonist's extreme actions (kidnapping plot) risk audience sympathy
Some scenes feel episodic rather than essential to story progression
Tendency toward overwriting in action blocks
Character transformation feels somewhat rushed in final act
core_quality.verdict_rationale: Solid romantic comedy with strong premise and good character work. The execution is professionally competent with effective escalation and payoffs. While it has clear weaknesses in pacing and character likability at times, the core concept is strong enough and the execution skilled enough to merit development consideration.

characters.protagonist: Melissa - late 20s photographer torn between artistic ambitions and relationship expectations. Her goal is initially to 'win' against Jonathan at the wedding, but evolves to helping repair the damage they've caused. Compelling due to her artistic passion and sister loyalty, though her revenge tactics sometimes push sympathy.
characters.antagonist: Jonathan - 30, successful tech entrepreneur and Melissa's ex. Not a traditional antagonist but rather the other half of the central conflict. His goal is also to 'win' the wedding war while dealing with his own hurt over the breakup.
supporting: Nicole - Type-A lawyer bride, Melissa's sister, perfectionist hiding pregnancy
Nick - laid-back groom, Jonathan's best friend, caught in the middle
Bradford - gay Stanford professor posing as Melissa's boyfriend, provides voice of reason
Jasper - Jonathan's toxic enabler friend who escalates the conflict
Robyn - actress hired as Jonathan's fake girlfriend, more intelligent than she appears

structure_analysis.act_breaks: Act 1 ends page 11 (breakup), Act 2 ends page 89 (hotel destruction)
structure_analysis.pacing: Generally solid pacing with good escalation. Some scenes in Act 2 (pages 45-65) feel slightly episodic. The revenge pranks build effectively toward the climax.

standout_scenes.scene: Shark attack sequence on the boat
standout_scenes.why: Perfect escalation of visual comedy with real consequences (ring loss)

standout_scenes.scene: Ruined photo montage at rehearsal dinner
standout_scenes.why: Great payoff to earlier setup, character-driven comedy
Satisfying resolution that brings all characters together

comparable_films.title: Wedding Crashers
comparable_films.similarity: Destination wedding setting with romantic complications
comparable_films.quality_comparison: Similar craft level but this has more character depth

comparable_films.title: Bridesmaids
comparable_films.similarity: Female-driven wedding comedy with relationship dynamics
comparable_films.quality_comparison: Weaker craft than Bridesmaids but similar ensemble approach

comparable_films.title: My Best Friend's Wedding
comparable_films.similarity: Romantic leads at someone else's wedding
comparable_films.quality_comparison: Similar structure but this is more raunchy, less sophisticated

strengths: Strong high-concept premise that generates natural conflict
Good character differentiation and ensemble work
Effective escalation of comedy through revenge pranks
Solid structural foundation with clear turning points
Visual comedy sequences work well (shark attack, hotel destruction)
weaknesses: Protagonist's actions sometimes alienate audience sympathy
Some scenes feel more episodic than essential
Overwriting in action blocks reduces readability
Character arcs feel somewhat rushed in resolution
Tonal balance between raunchy comedy and heart needs refinement
development_notes: Refine Melissa's character to maintain audience sympathy during revenge escalation
Tighten second act by removing or combining episodic scenes
Trim action blocks for better readability and pace
Develop the romantic resolution to feel more earned
Balance the raunch with more emotional depth in key moments

analysis.executive_summary: Solid romantic comedy with strong premise and professional execution. The escalating revenge war between exes at a destination wedding provides natural conflict and visual comedy opportunities, though protagonist likability and pacing issues need addressing.

cultural_resonance.rationale: Family loyalty, wedding traditions, and relationship dynamics translate well across Latin cultures. Sister bond especially resonates.

regional_casting_potential.rationale: Lead roles could work well for bilingual talent like Ana de la Reguera, Diego Luna, or rising Latin American stars. Ensemble nature provides multiple opportunities.

theatrical_appeal.rationale: Comedy works better with audiences but not spectacle-dependent. Dominican setting adds exotic appeal for Mexican audiences.

marketing_viability.rationale: Clear poster concept (bride and groom with exploding hotel), trailer would cut well with physical comedy. Hook: 'Love is war' translates perfectly.

coproduction_potential.rationale: Perfect for Mexico/US co-production with bilingual casting. Dominican setting could involve Caribbean co-production incentives.

specific_concerns: Some cultural references might need localization
Raunchy humor level appropriate for target markets
opportunities: Strong female ensemble appeals to key demographic

target_audience.note: Clear theatrical demo: women 25-54, couples, wedding comedy fans - sizeable market

high_concept.note: Perfect pitch: 'Exes forced to be maid of honor and best man destroy entire wedding resort'

cast_attachability.note: Two strong lead roles plus ensemble opportunities, mid-tier star vehicle

marketing_hook.note: Great trailer potential with physical comedy, clear poster image of exploding hotel

budget_return_ratio.note: Mid-budget with location costs but proven genre with good return potential

comparable_success.note: Wedding comedies have mixed record lately, but Crazy Rich Asians, Bridesmaids show upside

key_commercial_concerns: Need right cast to elevate material

key_cost_drivers: Hotel destruction VFX and practical effects $2-3M
Extended ensemble cast and wedding extras $2-3M
potential_savings: Shoot in Mexico doubling for DR to access incentives
Practical effects over VFX where possible
Cast rising talent versus established stars
assessment.location_requirements: Tropical resort location, multiple hotel interiors, beach, ocean sequences
assessment.vfx_requirements: moderate - hotel fire/explosion, some digital cleanup
assessment.justification: Destination wedding comedy with significant location requirements and moderate VFX for destruction sequences. Ensemble cast and tropical setting drive costs but within range.

development_priorities: Polish script for pacing and protagonist sympathy

mexico_us.rationale: Perfect bilingual casting opportunities, wedding comedy travels well, destination setting works for both markets
potential_partners: US indie prod cos specializing in Latino content
Major studio indie arms looking for diversity content

mexico_spain.rationale: Spanish language version potential, wedding comedy popular in Spain, but setting less relevant
mexico_spain.eu_fund_eligibility: Limited - not European enough for major EU funding but Spanish partner could access regional funds

other_territories.rationale: Wedding comedy is universal but no specific elements that would attract these partners

assessment.best_structure: Mexico/US co-production with bilingual casting strategy
treaty_considerations: Dominican Republic locations could qualify for Caribbean incentives
